summary.value:
This will be a 2x2 study in which the type of robot (humanoid vs. non-humanoid) and dehumanization (Yes vs. No) will be manipulated. 

All participants were told they would evaluate a robot. Before viewing the robot, participants in the dehumanization condition read the following statement (participants in the control condition immediately viewed the video clip): 

Although advanced robots can look similar to humans, they lack the most essential of human qualities--the ability to feel. Robots cannot experience love, desire, or any other emotions. They completely lack the ability to feel pain or pleasure. Unlike people, robots are not conscious; there is nothing that it is like to be them. Robots are merely a collection of cold silicon circuits.  

In the humanoid robot condition, participants were shown a 12-second clip of
Kaspar. In the control condition, participants were shown the same clip of Kaspar with a mechanical appearance. Still images of the video clips are available in the attached documents.

Finally, participants rated Kaspar's agency, experience, and uncanniness. 

We will use ANOVA to explore the main and interaction effects. We hypothesize that participants who were experimentally instructed to dehumanize would report lower feelings of uncanniness, mediated by reduced perceptions of robots' perceived experience.

Based on a conservative effective size estimate (partial eta squared = .01), we will need N = 779 for a power of 0.8. All participants will be recruited online via Prolific. We will furthermore embed an attention check question among the survey measure (i.e., please select 7 for this question). Participants who failed t his attention check will be dropped.

We will furthermore embed an attention check question among the survey measure (i.e., please select 7 for this question). Participants who failed t his attention check will be dropped.

attributes.title: MYSTAT Potentiostat/Galvanostat
attributes.description: Contains design files for the USB Potentiostat/Galvanostat described in "MYSTAT: A compact potentiostat/galvanostat for general electrochemistry measurements."

summary.value: This is a registration of the MYSTAT design files to be published in "MYSTAT: A compact potentiostat/galvanostat for general electrochemistry measurements."

registration_responses.summary: This is a registration of the MYSTAT design files to be published in "MYSTAT: A compact potentiostat/galvanostat for general electrochemistry measurements."

attributes.title: Evaluating a witness' testimony in an alleged rape case
attributes.description: This study investigates how mock jurors (participants recruited from Prolific) evaluate the female victim's testimony in cases of alleged rape

q1.value: How mock jurors evaluate the victim's testimony in cases of alleged rape

q2.value: Harrison Lee, Blake McKimmie, Barbara Masser, Jason M Tangen

q3.value:
The aim of the first study in this program of research was to test how mock jurors evaluated the testimony of a rape victim when it was presented chronologically or with the rape event first. Participants’ evaluations (i.e., whether the events described in the testimony depicted rape or consensual sex) were measured every second as they watched the video of the victim testifying by moving a slider along a scale. Using this design, we investigated how participants evaluated the overall testimony by recording the position of the slider at the end of the video. We also investigated how participants evaluated specific events described in this testimony (i.e., the rape event), by recording the position of the slider during certain parts of the video. Contrary to our predictions, participants in both testimony conditions did not differ in how they evaluated the overall testimony. However, participants who watched the testimony where the rape event was presented first evaluated this event as more depictive of rape compared to those who watched the testimony presented in a chronological order. This result suggests that participants who watched the rape event first testimony may be thinking about this information differently, compared to those who watched the chronological testimony (Sherman, Lee, Bessenoff, & Frost, 1998).

Additionally, the results of this study showed that the order in which the testimony was presented to participants influenced the variability in their responses regarding whether the events described by the victim were evaluated as rape or consensual sex. When the testimony was presented chronologically, participants moved the slider less often and less extremely between perceiving the testimony as depicting consensual sex or rape. In contrast, participants were far less consistent when the rape event was presented first in the testimony – that is, participants were much more variable in their responses using the slider. We interpret this difference in variation through the lens of the story model, which suggests that when events are presented chronologically in a trial, jurors find it easier to mentally organise these events into a story structure (Pennington & Hastie, 1988). Therefore, participants’ evaluations may have converged in the chronological testimony as the events were presented in a story format. This format may have allowed participants to make better sense of the testimony as it would have helped them mentally organise the described events into a coherent story (Pennington & Hastie, 1988). In contrast, participants who watched the testimony where the rape event (or the logical end to the story) was presented first may have been unable to organise the events into a coherent story. This lack of coherence may have led participants to feeling less certain as to whether the described events depicted rape or consensual sex. These unexpected results require further research to understand how participants are evaluating the events described in the victim’s testimony. 

The aim of the current study is the replicate the pattern of results revealed in the first study by asking participants to evaluate whether the events described by the victim depict rape or consensual sex (i.e., by responding with the same slider used in the first study). Further, we will investigate whether presenting the rape event first will cause participants to think about this event differently to those who watch the same testimony presented in chronological order. According to the Encoding Flexibility Model (Sherman et al., 1998), perceivers thoroughly encode the details of information that is inconsistent with their schemas. In contrast, perceivers tend to only remember the overall gist of information that is consistent with their schemas. Thus, we will assess participants’ memory of the specific details disclosed in the victim’s testimony to test whether they encode the rape event as schema consistent or inconsistent information.  

This study will also investigate whether presenting the rape event first in the victim’s testimony will influence how participants mentally organise the events described by the victim. Research shows that mock jurors are more persuaded when legal counsels present their evidence in a chronological order, as it organises this information for the juror into a coherent story (Pennington & Hastie, 1988). Pennington and Hastie (1986) tested how mock jurors mentally organise the events described in a trial by asking them to say out loud their thoughts when deciding on a verdict. Therefore, the current study will assess the extent to which participants mentally organise the events described in the victim’s testimony as a story, by asking them to write out their thoughts when deciding a verdict.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1 - We predict that, over the duration of the video, participants who watch the testimony where the rape event is presented first will be more likely to evaluate the events described in this testimony as rape than those who watch the chronological testimony. 

Hypothesis 2 - We predict that presenting the rape event first will increase participants’ perceptions of defendant guilt compared to those who watch the chronological testimony. 

Hypothesis 3 - We predict that participants who watch the chronological testimony will be more likely to mentally organise the events into a story compared to those who watch the testimony where the rape event is presented first. 

Hypothesis 4 - We predict that participants who watch the testimony where the rape event is presented first will remember more details about this event compared to those who watch the chronological testimony.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: Participants will be randomly allocated to one of two conditions to form the between-subjects manipulation of testimony order (chronological testimony, rape event first testimony). The key dependent variables in this study include participants’ categorisation of the events described in the victim’s testimony (as consensual sex or rape), the guilt likelihood measure, the choice of verdict measure, the written narrative measure, and a memory test assessing participant’s memory of the victim’s testimony. Participants will respond to the event categorisation measure by moving a slider as they watch the video of the victim’s testimony. The responses on this slider will be recorded every second and averaged to produce a mean score for every 10 seconds of video to operationalise the first repeated measures variable, time of video. The memory test will assess participants’ memory of two different types of events: the events which occurred before the rape, and the rape event. As such, the second repeated measures variable, event attention, will be operationalised by recording the percentage of questions each participant gets correct for these two event types.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly allocated to watch either the chronological testimony or the rape event first testimony. When participants start the online survey, they will be assigned either the letter “f” or the letter “c”. If participants are assigned the letter “f”, they will be assigned to watch the rape-first version of the testimony. If they are assigned the letter “c”, they will be assigned to watch the chronological testimony. This randomisation occurs in the programming script of the study and so participants are not aware of this allocation process.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from the Academic Prolific – an online platform that allows access to participants from Western countries. Participants will be excluded from participating in the study if they are under 18 years of age. This exclusion criterion is necessary as the minimum age to serve on a jury in Australia is 18 years old. Further, participants will be excluded from participating if they are not from Australia or the United Kingdom. This exclusion criterion is necessary so that participants are recruited from countries that have similar societal scripts about both consensual sex and rape. On the Prolific website, participants will see a number of available studies advertised. If a participant is eligible to participate, they can follow the link to the current study’s website. Participants will be paid £1.67 (British Pounds) or $3 AUD for their time.

q13.value: We will recruit 233 participants from Prolific.

q14.value: An a priori power analysis was conducted using G*Power to estimate the sample size required to power the current study at 0.95 power to detect an effect of f = 0.4 at an alpha value of 0.05. This effect size was used in the analysis after considering effect sizes found in the first study in this program of research. This power analysis revealed that a sample size of 86 participants will be needed to detect significant effects between each level of testimony order on the event categorisation measure. A separate power analysis was also conducted to estimate the sample size required to detect significant effects between each level of testimony order on the event attention measure. A medium effect size was used in the analysis since there is no research that has examined participants’ memory of different events described in a testimony. This analysis revealed that a sample size of 212 participants will be needed to test for significant interactions on the event attention measure. Given these results, we aim to collect data from 233 participants, which will ensure a sufficient sample size should any participants opt not to complete measures or need to be excluded from analyses (please refer to the attached "power analysis protocol" for more information).

q15.value: We will recruit participants until we reach our target sample size.

question.value:
We will manipulate testimony order by varying the order in which the victim describes the events in her testimony. In the chronological testimony, the victim will describe the events as they happened on the night of the alleged rape (i.e., the events which occurred before the alleged rape followed by the rape event). In the rape-first version of the testimony, the victim will first describe the rape event followed by the events which occurred before the rape (please see attached "testimony videos" for links to these videos on youtube).  

We will manipulate time of video by recording participants’ responses to the event categorisation measure. These responses will be averaged to produce a mean score for every 10 seconds of video. Both videos are approximately 380 seconds in length (please see attached "time of video syntax" for the code we will use to produce the mean scores for the time of video variable).

We will manipulate event attention by asking participants sixteen questions that assess their memory of two distinct clusters of events described by the victim: the events which occurred before the alleged rape and the rape event. Four of these questions will assess participants’ memory of the rape event, whereas twelve questions will assess their memory of the events which occurred before the alleged rape. The difference in the number of questions for each type of event is due to the comparative length of time the victim spends describing these events in the testimony. Please refer to the attached coding scheme for a list of these questions and more information about how they will be coded.

Event categorisation (please refer to the attached materials for a screenshot of what this measure looks like) will be assessed by asking participants: “Do the events described depict consensual sex or rape?” with the question being answered using a sliding scale that ranges from 1 (consensual sex) to 100 (rape).

Written narratives will be assessed by telling participants, “Now we would like you to start thinking about what verdict you think is appropriate for the defendant, Neil Fox. Please write down exactly what you are thinking as you decide whether the defendant is guilty or not guilty of rape. We would like you to write at least a small paragraph (60 to 100 words) in the space provided as you think about this decision.” Participants will respond to these instructions in the space below them.

Choice of verdict will be assessed using a single item: “Now please decide whether the defendant, Neil Fox, is guilty or not guilty of rape.” Participants may answer this question by selecting either “guilty” or “not guilty”. Guilt likelihood will be assessed using a single item: “How likely is it that Neil Fox (the defendant) is guilty of committing rape?” with participants responding on a 1 (not at all) to 7 (very likely) scale. 

The manipulation of testimony order will be assessed by one item: “At what point during the video did you hear Janine discuss the defendant forcing her down and penetrating her?” with participants responding on a 1 (very early in the video) to 7 (very late in the video) scale.

Event attention will be measured as described in the previous section.

Participants’ responses to the event categorisation measure will be recorded every second and averaged to produce a mean score for every 10 seconds of video. Participants’ answers to the memory test will be coded (1 = correct or 0 = incorrect) and averaged to form a percentage for each type of event (i.e., rape event questions and before rape event questions).

To test Hypothesis 1, a 2 (testimony order) by 38 (time of video) mixed factorial analysis of variance (ANOVA) will be conducted to test the effect of testimony order on how participants categorise the events of the testimony over the duration of the video. This analysis will include the interaction between testimony order and time of video. To test Hypothesis 2, an independent samples t-test will be run to test the differences between each level of testimony order on the guilt likelihood measure. A chi-square test will also be run to test the differences between each level of testimony order on the choice of verdict measure. To test Hypothesis 3, a content analysis will be conducted on participants’ responses to the written narrative measure by two raters who are blind to the condition that participants were assigned to. These raters will code the responses according to whether they follow the structure of a story. Specifically, these raters will first code the number of a) story statements and b) trial statements in each response. Next, these raters will code the number of story elements from the victim's testimony that are a) connected and b) not connected (please refer to the attached "coding scheme" for more information). To test Hypothesis 4, a 2 (testimony order) by 2 (event attention) mixed factorial ANOVA will be conducted to the test the effect of testimony order on participants’ memory of the events described. This analysis will include the interaction between testimony order and event attention.

q20.value: Participants’ answers to the memory test will be coded (1 = correct or 0 = incorrect) by the 1st author using a pre-determined coding scheme (you can see a copy of this coding scheme in the attached files). The content analysis on participants’ responses to the written narrative measure will also be coded using a pre-determined coding scheme. Pennington and Hastie (1986) used a similar coding scheme in their content analysis of interviews with mock jurors.

q21.value: We will use the standard p < 05 criteria for determining if the ANOVAs, t-tests, and the chi-square test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis was correct. For the independent samples t-tests, two tailed tests will be conducted.

q22.value: No awareness checks will be performed. Participants will be excluded from the analyses if they do not move the slider while they watch the video of the victim’s testimony. Participants will also be excluded from the final sample if they are missing at least 50% of their data.

q23.value: Any missing data will be treated under the guidelines of Pigott (2001), where participants will be excluded from the final sample if they are missing at least 50% of their data.

q24.value: Participants’ responses to the written narrative measure will be analysed using a text analytics tool (e.g., Leximancer) to identify common words, themes, and higher level concepts, and to assess the participants’ comprehension of the information conveyed in the testimony. If the planned analysis on the manipulation check assessment is non-significant, one-sample t-tests will be run to test if the means (of both testimony order conditions) are significantly different from the mid-point on the scale. A mixed factorial ANOVA may be run to test the effect of testimony order on participants’ responses to the event categorisation measure over the duration of the rape event. Specifically, participants’ responses to this measure will only be used in this analysis if they occur during the part of the video when the victim describes the rape event. We may also calculate the standard deviation for each participant’s responses to the event categorisation measure across the duration of the video. We will then conduct a two-tailed independent t-test to assess significant differences between participants’ standard deviations for each condition of testimony order.

q25.value:
Literature cited: 

Sherman, J. W., Lee, A. Y., Bessenoff, G. R., & Frost, L. A. (1998). Stereotype efficiency reconsidered: Encoding flexibility under cognitive load. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 75(3), 589-606. doi:10.1037/0022-3514.75.3.589

Pennington, N, & Hastie, R. (1986). Evidence evaluation in complex
decision making. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 51,
242-258

Pennington, N., & Hastie, R. (1986). Evidence evaluation in complex decision making. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 51(2), 242–258. https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-3514.51.2.242

Pennington, N., & Hastie, R. (1988). Explanation-based decision making: Effects of memory structure on judgment. Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition, 14(3), 521–533. https://doi.org/10.1037/0278-7393.14.3.521

We will manipulate event attention by asking participants sixteen questions that assess their memory of two distinct clusters of events described by the victim: the events which occurred before the alleged rape and the rape event. Four of these questions will assess participants’ memory of the rape event, whereas twelve questions will assess their memory of the events which occurred before the alleged rape. The difference in the number of questions for each type of event is due to the comparative length of time the victim spends describing these events in the testimony. Please refer to the attached coding scheme for a list of these questions and more information about how they will be coded.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Event categorisation (please refer to the attached materials for a screenshot of what this measure looks like) will be assessed by asking participants: “Do the events described depict consensual sex or rape?” with the question being answered using a sliding scale that ranges from 1 (consensual sex) to 100 (rape).

Written narratives will be assessed by telling participants, “Now we would like you to start thinking about what verdict you think is appropriate for the defendant, Neil Fox. Please write down exactly what you are thinking as you decide whether the defendant is guilty or not guilty of rape. We would like you to write at least a small paragraph (60 to 100 words) in the space provided as you think about this decision.” Participants will respond to these instructions in the space below them.

Choice of verdict will be assessed using a single item: “Now please decide whether the defendant, Neil Fox, is guilty or not guilty of rape.” Participants may answer this question by selecting either “guilty” or “not guilty”. Guilt likelihood will be assessed using a single item: “How likely is it that Neil Fox (the defendant) is guilty of committing rape?” with participants responding on a 1 (not at all) to 7 (very likely) scale. 

The manipulation of testimony order will be assessed by one item: “At what point during the video did you hear Janine discuss the defendant forcing her down and penetrating her?” with participants responding on a 1 (very early in the video) to 7 (very late in the video) scale.

Event attention will be measured as described in the previous section.
registration_responses.q18.question: Participants’ responses to the event categorisation measure will be recorded every second and averaged to produce a mean score for every 10 seconds of video. Participants’ answers to the memory test will be coded (1 = correct or 0 = incorrect) and averaged to form a percentage for each type of event (i.e., rape event questions and before rape event questions).
registration_responses.q19.question: To test Hypothesis 1, a 2 (testimony order) by 38 (time of video) mixed factorial analysis of variance (ANOVA) will be conducted to test the effect of testimony order on how participants categorise the events of the testimony over the duration of the video. This analysis will include the interaction between testimony order and time of video. To test Hypothesis 2, an independent samples t-test will be run to test the differences between each level of testimony order on the guilt likelihood measure. A chi-square test will also be run to test the differences between each level of testimony order on the choice of verdict measure. To test Hypothesis 3, a content analysis will be conducted on participants’ responses to the written narrative measure by two raters who are blind to the condition that participants were assigned to. These raters will code the responses according to whether they follow the structure of a story. Specifically, these raters will first code the number of a) story statements and b) trial statements in each response. Next, these raters will code the number of story elements from the victim's testimony that are a) connected and b) not connected (please refer to the attached "coding scheme" for more information). To test Hypothesis 4, a 2 (testimony order) by 2 (event attention) mixed factorial ANOVA will be conducted to the test the effect of testimony order on participants’ memory of the events described. This analysis will include the interaction between testimony order and event attention.

attributes.title: SARS-CoV-2 (2019-nCoV) 3CLpro Model & Screening
attributes.description: SARS-CoV-2 (2019-nCoV) 3CLpro model, virtual screening results and docking models

summary.value: This data project contains the Virtual Screening folder: model of SARS-CoV-2 3CLpro, screening/docking results of model A, B chains and those of the crystal structure. The Extended Results folder: SARS-CoV-2 substrate specificity, model 3D views, screening summary of crystal structure, comparison of models and crystal structure active sites. This registration is captured before publication on F1000Research.

registration_responses.summary: This data project contains the Virtual Screening folder: model of SARS-CoV-2 3CLpro, screening/docking results of model A, B chains and those of the crystal structure. The Extended Results folder: SARS-CoV-2 substrate specificity, model 3D views, screening summary of crystal structure, comparison of models and crystal structure active sites. This registration is captured before publication on F1000Research.

summary.value: This study aims at examining the existence and strength of specific links between self-reported dispositional mindfulness and various objetive measures of attention (phasic alertness, orienting and executive control) and vigilance (arousal and executive vigilance).

attributes.title: The Attitudes and Meaning About Math and Writing

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: We may explore whether there are other relations between the four major questions we test (e.g., how feelings and perceived meaning are related with each other). We may also code people’s meaning statements in other ways and do similar analyses as described above. We may also explore whether there are effects of demographic information (e.g., parent status, age, race, education etc.) on people’s responses.

sample.value: We will recruit 200 adults from MTurk

analyses.value:
We will do at least three types of analyses:
1)	For the feeling questions, we will code the valance of the words (-1=negative, 0=neutral, 1=positive). We will compare the average valance for math vs. writing (paired t-test), as well as whether the valance for math or writing is significantly different from the neutral point 0 (one-sample t-test). 
2)	For the meaning questions, we will code the meanings as intrinsic or extrinsic (not mutually exclusive), and we will compare the types of meanings mentioned for math vs. writing, for the self question vs. for explanations to a child (paired t-tests).  
3)	Relations with self-reports: We will explore how the feeling questions and the meaning questions are related to people’s self-reported attitudes towards and experiences with math. We may use a global self-report measure by combing all the questions, but may also use sub-scales as predictors. We may conduct pearson correlations, but also may use linear models:

model<- lm(meaning/feelings ~ experiences, data=data)
model<- lm(attitudes~ meaning/feelings, data=data)

4)	Relations with behavioral decision: We will explore whether the feelings questions and the meaning questions predict people’s behavioral decision.

model<- glmer(mathdecision~ math meaning/feelings/attitudes/experiences + (1|ID), family = binomial, control = glmerControl(optimizer = "bobyqa"), data=data)

model<- glmer(writingdecision~ writing meaning/feelings/attitudes/experiences + (1|ID), family = binomial, control = glmerControl(optimizer = "bobyqa"), data=data)

outliers.value: Responses that are incomplete, or people who endorse the two check statements (i.e., cheating on math or writing is morally good) will be excluded from the analyses.

dependent.value:
1) Feeling questions: We measure people’s feelings about math and writing by asking them to write down five adjectives that describe their feelings about math and writing.
2) Meaning questions: We measure people’s perceived meaning of learning math and writing skills by asking them two open-ended questions (i.e., why do we learn math/writing, and how to explain to a child why they need to learn math/writing).
3) Self-reports: We measure people’s attitudes and experiences about math and writing by giving them two questionnaires. 
4) Behavioral decision: we include a decision making measure at the end of the survey to measure people’s interest to learn math and writing skills.

conditions.value: Each participant will complete two within-subject conditions: math and writing. Half participants will complete questions on math first, and the other half participants will complete questions on writing first.

hypothesis.value:
1)	What are people’s feelings about math vs. writing?
2)	How do people understand the meanings of learning math skills vs. writing skills?
3)	Are people’s feelings and perceived meanings of math and writing related to their attitudes and experiences with math and writing?

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

We may also code people’s meaning statements in other ways and do similar analyses as described above. We may also explore whether there are effects of demographic information (e.g., parent status, age, race, education etc.) on people’s responses.

2)	For the meaning questions, we will code the meanings as intrinsic or extrinsic (not mutually exclusive), and we will compare the types of meanings mentioned for math vs. writing, for the self question vs. for explanations to a child (paired t-tests).  
3)	Relations with self-reports: We will explore how the feeling questions and the meaning questions are related to people’s self-reported attitudes towards and experiences with math. We may use a global self-report measure by combing all the questions, but may also use sub-scales as predictors. We may conduct pearson correlations, but also may use linear models:

model<- lm(attitudes~ meaning/feelings, data=data)

4)	Relations with behavioral decision: We will explore whether the feelings questions and the meaning questions predict people’s behavioral decision.

1) Feeling questions: We measure people’s feelings about math and writing by asking them to write down five adjectives that describe their feelings about math and writing.
2) Meaning questions: We measure people’s perceived meaning of learning math and writing skills by asking them two open-ended questions (i.e., why do we learn math/writing, and how to explain to a child why they need to learn math/writing).

attributes.title: Risky Choices on Behalf of Others
attributes.description: We investigate whether risky choices on behalf of others are any different than choices made on one's own behalf. We propose three different hypotheses that might explain differences. In addition, we include the potential hypotheses, experimental paradigms, operational variables, and analyses plan we plan to conduct for our results.

q1.value: Risky Choices on Behalf of Others

q3.value: Our primary goal is to determine whether risky choice made on behalf of someone else are systematically different than those made for oneself. To do that we propose two experiments.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Both experiments follow a 3 by 2 study design, they are both fully crossed and between-subjects. It is important to note that while all the conditions and procedure in both experiments are identical, the experimental tasks are different (see "Manipulation and Design" for each experiment).

q9.value: Participants are assigned to conditions in sequential order, thus it is not truly random. By "sequential" we mean that participants are assigned to their conditions depending on the last condition that was run. This is true for both experiments. We explain this and all caveats in both  "Manipulations and Design" documents.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: We will use undergraduate students at the University of Washington who are enrolled in any of the 101 introductory Psychology courses. They will participate in return for course-credit and a chance to win a cash prize of $200 (the latter is explained in more detail in the "Manipulation and Design" document). This is true for both experiments.

q13.value:
Experiments 1 and 2:

We stipulate a sample size of 540 participants, at least 90 per condition (but no more than 99 per condition). Thus, our sample size will consist of a minimum of 540 participants but no more than 594 per experiment.

q14.value: We used G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .8 power to detect an effect of .424 (based on a pilot) and alpha error of probability .05.

q15.value: We aim for 90 per condition but that exact number might not be possible because sessions are advertised days in advance and, thus, it is possible that more participants sign up than is needed (e.g. 89 participants' data have been collected, one short of the goal, but 10 people have signed up for the last session). To avoid data wasting we aim to run those participants. Thus, we will end the study with between 90-99 participants per condition.

question.value: Please see "Manipulations and Design" document for experiment 1 and experiment 2.

q24.value: Exploratory analyses will be conducted after confirmatory hypothesis so as to make informed analyses between groups. We might compare any combination between accountability and self-other on any of our dependent variables.

To avoid data wasting we aim to run those participants. Thus, we will end the study with between 90-99 participants per condition.
